This is a legitimate question and need to be answered with appropriate evidence to prove — or disprove — the early existence/presence of Tamils — or proto Tamils — in the island. So, what kind of evidences that can be correlated to prove existence of Tamils in the Island before historical period ? Well of course, inscriptions are not useful in proving presence of Tamils — or any other ethnic group for that matter — in island before 260 B.C.E. The knowledge of writing is introduced to India only during regime of Emperor Asoka (Falk 2018 : 63) . Though there are claims for pre-Asokan Brahmi(s) in Tamilakam and Sri Lanka, they are dismissed as inappropriate and mere graffitis without phoenotical values. [There are claims based on AMS dating, Begley(2004 : 521) argues AMS dating for Early Historic dating should be approached cautiously and should be not taken unless there are other evidence that supports it.] Therefore, by going with general consensus , it forces us to rely on archaeological evidence to reconstruct the history of the island before 260 BCE. It seems there was close relation between South India and Sri Lanka during megalithic period, they both used megalithic Black and Red ware , same glass ornaments , food crops , shared burial practices and iron technology (Begley 1967) Archaeologist Vimala Begley(1967) notes, We [Begley et al.] also visited several urn and cist burial sites. They assume a great importance in the archaeology of Ceylon because they show features analogous to those of South India.[1] The urns were earthen pots, large enough for a man in a sitting posture. They varied in size, the largest measuring 4 feet in height and 3 feet 6 inches in diameter. The dead men were placed in a sitting posture in an earthenware pot. The pot was then let into a pit and half filled with sand and rice, and other grains on a tray were placed before the dead man. His stone tools were also inserted at the sides of the pot. The foodstuff and the tools were no doubt, intended for the use of the dead man in his post-mortem life, for they believed in life of the spirit of men after death. The pot is buried under the soil. This kind of practice is common in South India and Sri Lanka. Apart from the burial practice, the people of Sri Lanka and Tamil Nadu used same glass for beads — and other jewellery (Dussubieux et al. 2010) . They used a type of soda-lime Aluminium glass for manufacturing glass ornaments all over Tamilakam and Sri Lanka (Dussubieux & Gratuze 2013:404)(Saxcé 2015 : 61–2). German Archaeologist H. Weisshaar (2015 : 208) states that, They [Sri Lankans] used Black and Red Ware (BRW) as in TamilNadu or Kerala, followed similar customs when they buried their dead in megalithic cemeteries, they used the same glass beads for jewellery and imported carnelian from the mainland[India]. The symbols inscribed in the vessels from Kodumanal — an early historic cum-Industrial site in Tamil Nadu — showed immense similarities with those found in the Island as jointly demonstrated by prof. K Rajan and O.Bopearachchi[2][3] Saxcé ( 2015: 60) says these symbols suggests close social and even close political and economic links between Tamil Nadu and southern Sri Lanka. The crop package of Sri Lanka and South India is same as noted by Murphy et al. 2018. The crop package patterns of Sri Lanka and South India includes, rice, millets , cotton, coconuts and others seems to share close similarities. Kantharodai, as one of Sri Lanka's four most important historic sites,appears to have a similar, parallel economic and urbanized development to other early south Indian and Sri Lankan urban centres such as Anuradhapura and Magama at the end of the Protohistoric period. During the Early Historic period, Sri Lanka was connected with the wider Indian Ocean with archaeological evidence of regular trade relations with the rest of South Asia, Southeast Asia and the Mediterranean world. The archaeobotanical assemblage recovered from Kirinda and Kantharodai does not demonstrate speciﬁc trade organization but does suggest connectivity between Southern India and Sri Lanka as they possess a similar crop package. (Murphy et al. 2018 : 12) Therefore, these evidences may be taken as early contact between South India — more precisely Tamilakam — and Sri Lanka and suggests early presence of South Indians in Island. How did the first Tamil people come to Sri Lanka ? The first arrival Tamil speaking people is may not precisely known. However, their arrival, in all likelihood, pre-dates the Indo-Aryans into island. The proto-Tamils must have arrived during beginning of Iron Age. The Indo-Aryans, in any means , are not autochthonous to the Subcontinent leave alone the island. The Arrival of Indo-Aryans into Indian subcontinent is dated around 1900 BCE , not directly ,from Kurgan culture of central Asia. This hypothesis is called Kurgan Theory. This theory, nevertheless, later revised into Steppe Hypothesis ( Anthony 2007). In fact, this is the most prefered theory among the ones that concerns about origin and diffusion of Indo-European language. From the Archaeological evidence , one can reconstruct following history : ** Presence of ancestors of Vedda people ** Around 1000 BCE : Arrivals of proto-Tamils from Deccan into Island and they do bring burial practices, food crops, iron and steel technology, and Black and Red ware. Around 500 BCE: Arrivals of Indo-Aryan men and they certainly did not replaced the people of Island. They do intermix with the local Tamils and non-Dravidic groups, and Tamils — and others— starts to speak Prakrits through Prakritisation. 1000 BCE to 300 BCE : Lord Siva-Phallus worship is major religion among the people (Maloney 1970 : 608-9). BC 500 : Emergence of urban settlements of Anuradhapura, Tissamaharama, Kandarodai (Jaffna) and Mantai. Vibrant commerce/exchanges between Tamil ports and Lankan ports. BC 262 : Emperor Ashoka sent Buddhist missionaries to Island and local rulers embrace Buddhism, and introduction of script into the island. BC 35: Pali Canon committed to writing in fourth Buddhist council at the island. CE 100 : Indo-Roman Trade. Reference : Falk, Harry 2018 : The Creation and Spread of Scripts in Ancient India. Weisshaar, Hans-Joachim 2015 , ‘Ancient Tissamaharama: The formation of urban structures and growing commerce’ in Sila Tripati (ed) ‘Maritime Contacts of the Past: Deciphering Connections Amongst Communities’ pp. 208-228. New Delhi: Delta Book World. , 2015. Charlene A Murphy, Dorian Fuller, Alison Weisskopf, N. Perera and Nicole Boivin 2018: ‘Early agriculture in Sri Lanka: New Archaeobotanical analyses and radiocarbon dates from the early historic sites of Kirinda and Kantharodai (Kandarodai)’ in Archaeological Research in Asia. Laure Dussubieux , Bernard Gratuze, Maryse Blet-Lemarquand 2010 : ‘Mineral soda alumina glass: occurence and meaning’ in Journal of Archaeological Science. Laure Dussubieux and Bernard Gratuze 2013: Glass in South Asia. Ariane de Saxcé 2015 : “Local networks and long-distance trade: the role of the exchanges between Sri Lanka and India during the Mediterranean trade”, in K. S. Mathew, éd., Imperial Rome, Muziris and the Indian Ocean, New Delhi : Manohar, 2015, pp. 53-73. Begley, Vimala 2004 : The Dating of Arikamedu and its Bearing on the Archaeology of Early Historical South India. David W. Anthony 2007 : The Horse, the Wheel and Language: How Bronze-Age Riders from the Eurasian Steppes Shaped the Modern World. Maloney, Clarence. “The Beginnings of Civilization in South India.” The Journal of Asian Studies, vol. 29, no. 3, 1970, pp. 603–616. JSTOR, The Beginnings of Civilization in South India. The problem with the common argument that the original inhabitants of Sri Lanka were Tamil is that linguistically the evidence isn’t there. There are phonemes in Sinhala and Sri Lankan Tamil that never appeared in southern India, namely the “ae” vowel (explaining why SL Tamils spell some names differently from Indian Tamil i.e. Dharmeratnam vs Dharmaratnam and Jeyaraj vs Jayaraj). Given that this vowel isn’t used in any Indo-Aryan or Dravidian language except possibly Kashmiri, it most likely originated with the pre-Sinhala/Tamil inhabitants. Furthermore there are a number of Sinhala words that have neither Indo-Aryan nor Dravidian origin. Again, they are probably remnants of the original language of SL.
